text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.15.3, Records and Information Management, Disposing of Records.

IRM 1.15.3.1 - Program Scope and Objectives - Removed speciﬁc reference numbers for the Records Control Schedules (RCS) and General Records Schedules (GRS) as updates to the schedules change the numerical references.
schedules change the numerical references. (
) IRM
- Unauthorized Disposition of Records - Changed the subsection title to correspond the content that includes Records Loss Reporting and use of Form
, Records Loss Reporting. Also, removed speciﬁc reference numbers for the Records Control Schedules (RCS) as updates to the schedules change the numerical references. (
) IRM
- Form
, Certiﬁcate of (In-house) Records Disposal - Changed subsection title from In-House Destruction of Records. Expanded content on referencing paper or electronic records and on the use of Form
, Certiﬁcate of Records Disposal, for disposal of electronic system data/records. (
) IRM references, website links, and editorial updates have been made throughout this IRM section.

IRM 1.15.3.4 - Unauthorized Disposition of Records - Changed the subsection title to correspond with the content that includes Records Loss Reporting and use of Form 15035, Records Loss Reporting. Also, removed speciﬁc reference numbers for the Records Control Schedules (RCS) as updates to the schedules change the numerical references.

IRM 1.15.3.8 - Form 11671, Certiﬁcate of (In-house) Records Disposal - Changed subsection title from In-House Destruction of Records. Expanded content on referencing paper or electronic records and on the use of Form 11671, Certiﬁcate of Records Disposal, for disposal of electronic system
IRM references, website links, and editorial updates have been made throughout this IRM
This IRM supersedes IRM 1.15.3 dated August 4,

In keeping with the mission of the Records and mation Management (RIM) Program to improve the quality of, document, protect, and efficiently manage all IRS records until ﬁnal disposition, a local procedure has been developed to record all internal records disposals. (
) Audience: These procedures apply to ALL IRS employees and contractors. (

) Program Owner: The Records and Information Management (RIM) office, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD) is the program office responsible for oversight of the Servicewide records management (

) The protection of information is of vital concern to the Service. Every effort must be made to ensure that all documents are provided protection surate with the information therein. Not all record disposals are conducted the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) Federal Records Centers (FRCs). Most IRS records disposal actions are actually performed house by various vendors under shredding contracts, or are conducted by employees using Federal equipment. (
) The Archivist of the United States is the sole authority for destruction of all federal records,

Code of to Destroy Federal Regulations (CFR) Chapter XII. Records may only be destroyed in cordance with authorized instructions found in the IRS Records Control Schedules (RCS). Note: Site audit records are subject to the Government Accountability Office disposal authority. ), which may be reproduced, is to used to certify the destruction of IRS records for court purposes. Records cialists are authorized to issue notarized destruction certiﬁcations after veriﬁcation that a particular accession of records or that a particular record been destroyed. (

) Unauthorized disposition is the removal from the legal custody of the Federal government or the alienation, alteration, or mutilation of records without to the provisions of IRS Records Control Schedules located in IRS
, Catalog
D and General Records Schedules (GRS) located in Document
, Catalog

E . Note: The IRS is required to “notify the Archivist” at the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA), of any actual, impending, or threatened unlawful removal, defacing, alteration, corruption, deletion, erasure, or destruction of records in the custody of the agency. (

) The Records and Information Management (RIM) Program office manages Records Loss Reporting (RLR) process for investigating, analyzing and reporting IRS incidents involving the loss, theft or destruction of records. Records loss is deﬁned as the theft or unauthorized destruction, deletion, or removal of any record or device containing records under an employee’s control, which cannot be recreated or restored. (

) Immediately upon becoming aware of a loss, theft, or unauthorized of a hardcopy or electronic record, contractors and IRS employees must the loss using the Personally Identiﬁable Information (PII) Breach Reporting Form. The PGLD Incident Management (IM) office will review the PII Breach Reporting Form as outlined in IRM
, Incident Management Program, alert the PGLD RIM Program office that a suspected records loss has occurred. Upon receipt of the Records Loss Report from the IM office, RIM
) Destruction Certiﬁcation (Exhibit

), which may be reproduced, is to be used to certify the destruction of IRS records for court purposes. Records Spe- cialists are authorized to issue notarized destruction certiﬁcations after veriﬁcation that a particular accession of records or that a particular record has been destroyed.

Unauthorized disposition is the removal from the legal custody of the Federal government or the alienation, alteration, or mutilation of records without regard to the provisions of IRS Records Control Schedules located in IRS Document 12990, Catalog 57910D and General Records Schedules (GRS) located in IRS Document 12829, Catalog 54713E .

The Records and Information Management (RIM) Program office manages the Records Loss Reporting (RLR) process for investigating, analyzing and reporting IRS incidents involving the loss, theft or destruction of records. Records loss is deﬁned as the theft or unauthorized destruction, deletion, or removal of any record or device containing records under an employee’s control, which cannot be recreated or restored. Immediately upon becoming aware of a loss, theft, or unauthorized destruction of a hardcopy or electronic record, contractors and IRS employees must the loss using the Personally Identiﬁable Information (PII) Breach Reporting
Records and Information Management
contact the reporting point of contact to complete Form 15035 , Records Loss Reporting. The RIM Program office will conduct an intake and risk assessment process that includes:
Management Mailbox. Intake also includes performing an initial assess

ment to determine if an incident meets the deﬁnition of a records loss. Risk assessment: Assessing risk to determine if records are retrievable or cannot be otherwise reconstructed. Records Loss Notiﬁcation: Notifying NARA of records loss, if necessary. Remediation: Facilitating or partnering with affected records custodian to provide recommendations on preventing similar future occurrences.
Remediation: Facilitating or partnering with affected records custodian to provide recommendations on preventing similar future occurrences.

Additionally, the penalty for loss or unauthorized destruction of federal records, whether paper or electronic, through negligence or carelessness can range from written reprimand to suspension or removal. See IRM 1.15.5, Relocating/ Removing Records, for the penalties on unlawful removal, alienation, or destruction of government records. The IRS Records Officer must furnish a report to NARA after each conﬁrmed incident of erroneous records destruc- tion. Records Loss Reporting is included in the annual Records Management Mandatory Brieﬁng, Integrated Talent Management (ITM) course 62965. Further information on the Records Loss Reporting process and Form 15035 , Records Loss Reporting can be found at RIM’s Records Loss Report- ing website.
Under certain conditions, records may be destroyed without regard to the IRS RCS. Also see 36 CFR 1229, Emergency Authorization to Destroy Records.

When such records are identiﬁed, notify the IRS Records Officer, who inform the IRS Commissioner, who will then notify NARA, specifying the nature of the records, their location and quantity, and the nature of the danger. If NARA concurs, the Archivist of the United States will direct the immediate destruction of the records.

If any still or motion picture ﬁlm on nitrocellulose base has become soft, sticky, is emitting a noxious odor, contains gas bubbles, or has deteriorated to an acrid powder, the IRS Commissioner shall, without prior NARA authorization, arrange for its destruction, whether by burial in landﬁlls or by arranging for salvage destruction for its silver content when sufficient quantity warrants such salvage. In any case, such ﬁlm should be removed from occupied buildings as soon as possible. Within

days after destruction, the IRS Records Officer shall notify the IRS Commissioner and submit a statement to NARA, College Park, Maryland, describing the ﬁlm and showing when, where, and how destruction was ac- complished.
of Records

page a. Outside the territorial limits of the United States, records may be destroyed during a state of war between the United States and any nation or when hostile action by a foreign power seems imminent. Only the IRS Commissioner may make such a determination and that the records’ retention would be prejudicial to the United States’ interests or are occupying space needed for military purposes and are without suffi- cient administrative, legal, research, or other value to warrant their continued preservation. b. Within six months after the destruction, the IRS Commissioner shall submit to NARA a written statement describing the character of any records destroyed and showing when and where destruction was plished. (

) Disposal lists are for non-recurrent records. These lists provide one-time authority for the immediate disposal of existing records no longer and having no further value or no longer being created. These lists can be thorized only by the IRS Records Officer, and individual offices are for notifying their Information Resource Coordinator (IRC) and Records Spe- cialist of the need for such a list. Example: Create and use disposal lists for administrative records associated with incomplete projects or programs, or for record series that are frozen legal purposes and submit to the Records Specialist. (
) The IRS Records Officer will develop records disposition lists as required or based on information submitted by Records Specialists from the IRCs. (
) When records at the FRC are eligible for destruction, the FRC issues a Form NA-
, Notice of Eligibility for Disposal, at least
days before the date of Records the records are scheduled for destruction. The Records Specialists verify the Records information on the Forms NA-
against their reference copies of the SF-
forms provided at the time of retirement. A copy of each NA-
, with cover letter stating agreement to destroy the subject records will be sent to appropriate IRC for review and coordination. The IRC determines:

Only the IRS Commissioner may make such a determination and that the records’ retention would be prejudicial to the United States’ interests or are occupying space needed for military purposes and are without cient administrative, legal, research, or other value to warrant their continued preservation. b. Within six months after the destruction, the IRS Commissioner shall submit to NARA a written statement describing the character of any records destroyed and showing when and where destruction was plished.

The IRC or the appropriate manager will submit written justiﬁcation to the Records Specialist within

days why the records should not be destroyed at this time. In addition, a new or proposed disposal date should be provided by the office of record with their request. The Records Specialist then forwards the request to the IRS Records Officer for action and coordination with the FRC.
Officer for action and coordination with the FRC. (
) Agreements with the FRC Program will include requirements for compliance with physical security requirements for protection of IRC
records. NARA may use outside vendors to accomplish destruction of IRS records. These dors will be obligated to comply with Section

Non-Disclosure require- ments for the protection of taxpayer and other records containing sensitive information. These sites will be inspected by IRS Physical Security personnel prior to beginning a destruction of IRS records and will be subject to random and unannounced inspections thereafter. (
) IRS Form

, Certiﬁcate of Records Disposal, documents the in-house disposition of original paper and electronic IRS records. Some series of IRS Certiﬁcate records are maintained throughout their entire life cycle in a single office or in Records IRS maintained space (including non-recordkeeping electronic systems) than retired to a FRC. The recurring series of records that fall under this category must be identiﬁed prior to destruction or deletion. Should they be required for work purposes, for Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requesting or Congressional requesting purposes, or be needed for court purposes, the IRS would have to identify the exact date when the records were destroyed and under what authority. IRS Form

should be used to identify the of record, the manager approving the disposal, the series/system being disposed, the RCS/GRS and Item Number, the inclusive dates of the records, the volume (number of boxes being destroyed or amount of data being deleted), and the date of the destruction. IRS records, paper or electronic, series being destroyed or deleted in-house (with exceptions, see below) be documented in this manner. Completed IRS Form

, Certiﬁcate of Records Disposal should be forwarded to the Records Specialist assigned to the Post of Duty for processing. Note: The in-house destruction/deletion of non-record copies, including reference copies, does not require the completion of Form

The recurring series of records that fall under this category must be identiﬁed prior to destruction or deletion. should be used to identify the office of record, the manager approving the disposal, the series/system being disposed, the RCS/GRS and Item Number, the inclusive dates of the records, the volume (number of boxes being destroyed or amount of data being deleted), and the date of the destruction. ) Guidance on the use of this form and the processes for carrying out in-house records destruction/deletion are available on the Records and Information agement (RIM) Program Shar
oint. (

) When possible, paper records will be sold as waste. The contract for the sale will prohibit resale or use as records or documents and will prohibit sales of shredded documentation to foreign located entities. The contract will further state that records containing protected information, such as taxpayer privacy act data, will be destroyed beyond legibility or reconstruction. See the Physical Security Handbook for approved methods of destruction, e.g. shredding, burning or pulping. All sites where IRS paper is shredded, macerated, pulped, or burned, will be available for inspection by Disclosure personnel. (
) The Privacy Act Notiﬁcation and the clause entitled Privacy Act, See
CFR Subpart
CFR
, and
CFR Subtitle A, Part

, Subpart C, should also be included in the contract. If the material is removed from the IRS facility under circumstances that prohibit immediate destruction, the container used for removal must lock in such a manner that a seal may applied. The seal will then be removed by the witnessing IRS employee at time of destruction. (

) For small quantities, paper records may be donated to local public or institutions or agencies for the purposes of recycling. IRS personnel must the necessary precautions to ensure that the materials are not sold as documents and that the interests of the United States and of private are protected. In all cases, donations of records must be approved and rized by the IRS Records Officer prior to transferring of the records for these purposes. (

) To serve the public interest, the IRS may donate records authorized for disposal to another government agency, organization, institution, corporation person that has made application for them. The following terms must be met: a. The proposed recipient agrees not to sell the records as records or documents; b. The donation is made without cost to the United States government; c. The records do not contain information, the disclosure of which is ited by law or would be contrary to the public interest (no IRC

re- cords may be donated under this purpose); d. Donations to a foreign government will not be approved unless such a government has an official interest in the records which is amenable to that of the United States government; and e. Donations to persons or commercial businesses will not be approved less the records are directly related to the custody or operation of ties acquired from the United States government. (

) If, in the opinion of management officials the donation is acceptable, approval of the proposed donation must be obtained through: a. Local management officials and b. The IRS Records Officer. Internal Revenue Manual
